revision.comment: /* Historical accuracy */ Edited to more accurately reflect the selected quote.
revision.text:
{{about|the film|the book on which it is based|Hidden Figures (book)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}}
{{Infobox film | name = Hidden Figures | image = The official poster for the film Hidden Figures, 2016.jpg | alt = Three women standing in the foreground. In the background a rocket is launching. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Theodore Melfi]] | producers = {{Plainlist| * [[Donna Gigliotti]] * [[Peter Chernin]] * [[Jenno Topping]] * [[Pharrell Williams]] * Theodore Melfi }} | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * [[Allison Schroeder]] * Theodore Melfi }} | based on = {{based on|''[[Hidden Figures (book)|Hidden Figures]]''|[[Margot Lee Shetterly]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Taraji P. Henson]] * [[Octavia Spencer]] * [[Janelle Monáe]] * [[Kevin Costner]] * [[Kirsten Dunst]] * [[Jim Parsons]]<!--PER BILLING--> }} | music = {{Plain list| * [[Hans Zimmer]] * [[Pharrell Williams]] * [[Benjamin Wallfisch]] }} | cinematography = [[Mandy Walker]] | editing = [[Peter Teschner]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Fox 2000 Pictures]] * [[Chernin Entertainment]] * Levantine Films }} | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{film date|2016|12|10|[[School of Visual Arts|SVA Theatre]]|2016|12|25|United States}} | runtime = 127 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 126:37--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/hidden-figures-film|title=''Hidden Figures''|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|accessdate=December 10, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25 million<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goldrich|first1=Robert|title=Fall 2016 Director's Profile: Ted Melfi|url=https://www.shootonline.com/news/fall-2016-directors-profile-ted-melfi|website=[[Shoot (advertising magazine)|Shoot]]|accessdate=December 22, 2016}}</ref> | gross = $236 million<ref name=BOM>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hiddenfigures.htm|title=Hidden Figures (2016)|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=January 6, 2018}}</ref> | border = no |IMDB Rating= 7.8/10 }}
'''''Hidden Figures''''' is a 2016 American [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Theodore Melfi]] and written by Melfi and [[Allison Schroeder]]. It is loosely based on the [[non-fiction]] book [[Hidden Figures (book)|of the same name]] by [[Margot Lee Shetterly]] about black female [[mathematician]]s who worked at the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) during the [[Space Race]]. The film stars [[Taraji P. Henson]] as [[Katherine Johnson]], a mathematician who calculated flight trajectories for [[Project Mercury]] and other missions. The film also features [[Octavia Spencer]] as NASA supervisor and mathematician [[Dorothy Vaughan]] and [[Janelle Monáe]] as NASA engineer [[Mary Jackson (engineer)|Mary Jackson]], with [[Kevin Costner]], [[Kirsten Dunst]], [[Jim Parsons]], [[Glen Powell]], and [[Mahershala Ali]] in supporting roles.
Principal photography began in March 2016 in [[Atlanta]] and was wrapped up in May 2016. ''Hidden Figures'' had a limited release on December 25, 2016, by [[20th Century Fox]], before going wide in the United States on January 6, 2017. The film received positive reviews from critics and grossed $236 million worldwide. It was chosen by [[National Board of Review]] as one of the top ten films of 2016<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalboardofreview.org/award-years/2016/ |title=National Board of Review Announces 2016 Award Winners |publisher=[[National Board of Review]] |date=November 29, 2016 |accessdate=November 29, 2016}}</ref> and was nominated for numerous awards, including three [[Academy Award|Oscar nominations]] ([[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] for Spencer), and two [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globes]] ([[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Motion Picture|Best Supporting Actress]] for Spencer and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]]). It also won the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]].
==Plot== In [[1961 in the United States|1961]], mathematician [[Katherine Johnson|Katherine Goble]] works as a [[human computer]] in the [[sex segregation|gender segregated]] and [[Racial segregation in the United States|racially segregated]] division [[West Area Computers]] of the [[Langley Research Center]] in [[Hampton, Virginia]], alongside her colleagues, aspiring engineer [[Mary Jackson (engineer)|Mary Jackson]] and their unofficial acting-supervisor [[Dorothy Vaughan]].
Following the successful [[Soviet]] launch of [[Yuri Gagarin]], pressure to send American [[astronaut]]s into space increases. Supervisor Vivian Mitchell assigns Katherine to assist Al Harrison's [[Space Task Group]], given her skills in [[analytic geometry]]. She becomes the first black woman on the team.
Katherine's new colleagues are initially dismissive and demeaning, especially head engineer Paul Stafford. Meanwhile, Mitchell informs Dorothy that she will not be promoted, as there are no plans to assign a "permanent supervisor for the colored group". Mary is assigned to the space capsule [[heat shield]] team, and immediately identifies a flaw. With encouragement from the team leader, a Polish-Jewish Holocaust survivor, she submits an application for an official NASA engineer position and begins to pursue additional engineering coursework, as she already has a mathematics and physical science degree, but needs additional certification courses offered only through the all-white nearby Hampton high school. First, Mary successfully petitions a local judge to grant her legal authorization to attend the segregated all white school.
Katherine meets [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] Lt. Col. Jim Johnson at a barbecue, but she is disappointed when he voices skepticism about women's mathematical abilities. He later apologizes, and begins spending time with Katherine and her three daughters.
When Harrison invites his subordinates to solve a complex [[mathematical equation]], Katherine develops the solution, leaving him impressed. The [[Mercury Seven|Mercury 7]] astronauts visit Langley and astronaut [[John Glenn]] is cordial to the West Area Computers.
Harrison is enraged when he finds out that Katherine is forced to walk a half-mile (800 meters) to another building to use the colored people's bathroom. Harrison abolishes bathroom segregation, knocking down the "Colored Bathroom" sign. Harrison allows Katherine to be included in their meetings, in which she creates an equation within that meeting to guide the space capsule during re-entry. Despite this, Katherine is forced to remove her name from the reports, which are credited solely to Stafford. Stafford said that computers cannot author such things. Meanwhile, Mary goes to court and convinces the judge to grant her permission to attend night classes in an all-white school to obtain her engineering degree.
Dorothy learns of the impending installation of an [[IBM 7090]] electronic computer that could replace human computers. She visits the computer room to learn about it, and successfully starts the machine. Later, she visits a public library, where the librarian scolds her for visiting the whites-only section, to borrow a book about [[Fortran]]. She stole that book and began studying on her own. After teaching herself programming and training her West Area co-workers, she is officially promoted to supervise the Programming Department, bringing 30 of her co-workers with her. Mitchell eventually addresses Dorothy as "Mrs. Vaughan," indicating her new-found respect.
As the final arrangements for [[Mercury-Atlas 6|John Glenn's launch]] are made, Katherine is reassigned back to West Area Computers. Harrison told her that they no longer needs computer in their department and it's beyond his decision. As a wedding and farewell gift from her colleagues (Katherine is now married to Jim Johnson), Katherine is given a pearl necklace, the only jewelry allowed under the dress code.
The day of the launch, discrepancies arise in the IBM 7090 calculations for the capsule's landing coordinates, and Astronaut Glenn requests that Katherine be called in to check them. She quickly does so, only to have the door slammed in her face after delivering the results to the control room. However, Harrison gives her a security pass so they can relay the results to Glenn together. After a successful launch and orbit, the space capsule has a heat shield problem. Mission control decides to land it after three orbits instead of seven. Katherine suggests that they leave the retro-rocket attached to the heat shield for reentry. The instructions prove correct, and [[Friendship 7]] successfully lands.
Following the mission, the mathematicians are laid off and ultimately replaced by electronic computers. Katherine is reassigned to the Analysis and Computation Division, Dorothy continues to supervise the Programming Department, and Mary obtains her engineering degree and gains employment at NASA as an engineer. At the end of the film, we see Stafford, showing a change of heart, bringing Katherine a cup of coffee and accepting that her name is included on the report.
An [[epilogue]] reveals that Katherine calculated the trajectories for the [[Apollo 11]] and [[Space Shuttle]] missions. In 2015 she was awarded the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]. The following year, NASA dedicated the [[Langley Research Center]]'s Katherine G. Johnson Computational Building in her honor.
== Cast == {{div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Taraji P. Henson]] as [[Katherine Johnson|Katherine Goble Johnson]], mathematician * [[Octavia Spencer]] as [[Dorothy Vaughan]], mathematician and supervisor * [[Janelle Monáe]] as [[Mary Jackson (engineer)|Mary Jackson]], mathematician and engineer * [[Kevin Costner]] as Al Harrison, director of the Space Task Group * [[Kirsten Dunst]] as Vivian Mitchell, supervisor * [[Jim Parsons]] as Paul Stafford, head engineer in STG * [[Glen Powell]] as [[John Glenn]], astronaut * [[Mahershala Ali]] as Jim Johnson, military officer who romances and eventually marries Katherine * Karan Kendrick as Young Joylette Coleman, mother of Young Katherine Goble Johnson * Donna Biscoe as Joylette Coleman, Katherine's mother, who helps care for her children * [[Rhoda Griffis]] as White Librarian * [[Maria Howell]] as Ms. Summer * [[Aldis Hodge]] as Levi Jackson * Paige Nicollette as Eunice Smith * [[Gary Weeks]] as Reporter at Press Conference * [[Saniyya Sidney]] as Constance Johnson * Zani Jones Mbayise as Kathy Johnson * [[Kimberly Quinn (actress)|Kimberly Quinn]] as Ruth * [[Olek Krupa]] as Karl Zielinski, engineer who encourages Mary Jackson {{div col end}}
== Production == On July 9, 2015, it was announced that producer [[Donna Gigliotti]] had acquired Margot Lee Shetterly's nonfiction book ''Hidden Figures'', about a group of black female mathematicians that helped NASA win the [[Space Race]].<ref name="Jul2015D">{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=Ted Melfi & Fox 2000 In Talks For 'Hidden Figures'; How A Group Of Math-Savvy Black Women Helped NASA Win Space Race|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/ted-melfi-hidden-figures-black-women-mathematicians-help-nasa-win-space-race-fox-2000-1201473028/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=July 9, 2015}}</ref> [[Allison Schroeder]] wrote the script, which was developed by Gigliotti through Levantine Films. Schroeder grew up by Cape Canaveral and her grandparents worked at NASA, where she also interned as a teenager, and as a result saw the project as a perfect fit for herself.<ref name="creativescreenwriting.com">{{cite news|last1=McKittrick|first1=Christopher|title=Hidden Figures: "A Mathematical Juggling Act"|url=https://creativescreenwriting.com/hidden-figures/|accessdate=February 1, 2017|work=creativescreenwriting.com|date=February 1, 2017}}</ref> Levantine Films produced the film with [[Peter Chernin]]'s [[Chernin Entertainment]]. [[Fox 2000 Pictures]] acquired the film rights, and Theodore Melfi signed on to direct.<ref name="Jul2015D" /> After coming aboard, Melfi revised Schroeder's script, and in particular focused on balancing the home lives of the three protagonists with their careers at NASA.<ref name="creativescreenwriting.com"/> After the film's development was announced, actresses considered to play the black female roles included [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Viola Davis]], [[Octavia Spencer]], and [[Taraji P. Henson]].<ref name="Jul2015D" />
Chernin and [[Jenno Topping]] produced, along with Gigliotti and Melfi.<ref name="Feb2016V">{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Taraji P. Henson to Play Math Genius in New Film 'Hidden Figures'|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/taraji-p-henson-hidden-figures-katherine-johnson-1201702679/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|work=Variety|date=February 10, 2016}}</ref> On February 10, 2016, Fox cast Henson to play the lead role of mathematician [[Katherine Johnson|Katherine Goble Johnson]]. On February 17, Spencer was selected to play [[Dorothy Vaughan]], one of the three lead mathematicians at NASA.<ref name="SpencerCast">{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Octavia Spencer to Play Mathematician Opposite Taraji P. Henson in 'Hidden Figures' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/octavia-spencer-taraji-p-henson-mathematicians-hidden-figures-1201708407/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|work=Variety|date=February 17, 2016}}</ref> On March 1, 2016, [[Kevin Costner]] was cast in the film to play the fictional head of the space program.<ref name="CostnerCast">{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Kevin Costner Joins Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer in 'Hidden Figures' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kevin-costner-hidden-figures-taraji-henson-octavia-spencer-1201718423/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|work=Variety|date=March 1, 2016}}</ref> Singer [[Janelle Monáe]] signed on to play the third lead mathematician, Mary Jackson.<ref name="MonaeCast">{{cite news|last1=Sneider|first1=Jeff|title=Janelle Monae Joins Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer in Fox 2000's 'Hidden Figures' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.thewrap.com/janelle-monae-joins-taraji-p-henson-octavia-spencer-in-fox-2000s-hidden-figures-exclusive/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|work=TheWrap|date=March 7, 2016}}</ref> Later the same month, [[Kirsten Dunst]], [[Glen Powell]], and [[Mahershala Ali]] were cast in the film: Powell to play astronaut John Glenn,<ref name="ParsonsCast" /> and Ali as Johnson's love interest.<ref name="DunstCast">{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=Kirsten Dunst Joins Ted Melfi-Directed ‘Hidden Figures’ At Fox 2000|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/kirsten-dunst-hidden-figures-nasa-female-mathematicians-ted-melfi-fox-2000-1201718654/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Mar2016D">{{cite news|last1=Busch|first1=Anita|title=Ted Melfi's 'Hidden Figures' Adds Glen Powell & Mahershala Ali|url=http://deadline.com/2016/03/hidden-figures-movie-mahershala-ali-glen-powell-cast-1201720799/|accessdate=March 27, 2016|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 15, 2016}}</ref>
[[Principal photography]] began in March 2016 on the campus of [[Morehouse College]] in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=On the Set for 3/11/16: Taraji P. Henson & Octavia Spencer Team Up for 'Hidden Figures' While Jordan Peele, Allison Williams & Catherine Keener Wrap 'Get Out'|url=http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-31116-taraji-p-henson-octavia-spencer-team-up-for-hidden-figures-while-jordan-peele-allison-williams-catherine-keener-wrap-get-out/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|work=SSN Insider|date=March 11, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312080144/http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-31116-taraji-p-henson-octavia-spencer-team-up-for-hidden-figures-while-jordan-peele-allison-williams-catherine-keener-wrap-get-out/|archivedate=March 12, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Filming also took place at [[Lockheed Martin Aeronautics]] at [[Dobbins Air Reserve Base]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walljasper|first1=Matt|title=What's Filming in Atlanta Now? Baby Driver, Hidden Figures, and a grim warning of things to come|url=http://www.atlantamagazine.com/news-culture-articles/whats-filming-in-atlanta-now-baby-driver-hidden-figures-and-a-grim-warning-of-things-to-come/|accessdate=March 26, 2016|work=Atlanta Magazine|date=March 24, 2016}}</ref> On April 1, 2016, [[Jim Parsons]] was cast in the film to play the head engineer of the Space Task Group at NASA, Paul Stafford.<ref name="ParsonsCast">{{cite news|last1=Busch|first1=Anita|title=Jim Parsons Joins Ted Melfi’s ‘Hidden Figures’ For Fox 2000|url=http://deadline.com/2016/04/jim-parsons-hidden-figures-movie-big-bang-theory-1201729806/|accessdate=April 2, 2016|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=April 1, 2016|language=English}}</ref> In April 2016, [[Pharrell Williams]] came on board as a producer on the film. He also wrote original songs and handled the music department and soundtrack of the film, with [[Hans Zimmer]] and [[Benjamin Wallfisch]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Galuppo|first1=Mia|title=Pharrell Williams to Produce, Write Music for Fox 2000's 'Hidden Figures'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pharrell-williams-produce-write-music-880911|accessdate=April 8, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=April 5, 2016}}</ref> [[Morehouse College]] [[mathematics]] [[professor]] [[Rudy Horne|Rudy L. Horne]] was brought in to be the on-set mathematician.
==Historical accuracy== The film, set at NASA Langley Research Center in 1961, depicts segregated facilities such as the West Area Computing unit, where an all-black group of female mathematicians were originally required to use separate dining and bathroom facilities. However, in reality, Dorothy Vaughan was promoted to supervisor of West Computing in 1949, becoming the first black supervisor at the [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics]] (NACA) and one of the few female supervisors. In 1958, when NACA became NASA, segregated facilities, including the West Computing office, were abolished. Dorothy Vaughan and many of the former West Computers transferred to the new Analysis and Computation Division (ACD), a racially and gender-integrated group.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/content/dorothy-vaughan-biography |title=Dorothy Vaughan Biography | NASA |publisher=Nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=January 30, 2017}}</ref>
Mary Jackson was the one who had to find her own way to a colored bathroom, which did exist on the East Side.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures|last=Shetterly|first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|page=108}}</ref> Katherine (then Goble) was originally unaware that the East Side bathrooms were segregated, and used the unlabeled "whites-only" bathrooms for years before anyone complained.<ref name="Khan">{{cite news |last=Khan |first=Amina |date=February 26, 2017 |title=Q&A: Our interview with Katherine G. Johnson, the real-life mathematician who inspired 'Hidden Figures' |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-oscars-2017-89th-academy-awards-q-a-our-interview-with-katherine-g-1488161846-htmlstory.html |work=LA Times |location=Los Angeles |accessdate=March 1, 2017}}</ref> She ignored the complaint, and the issue was dropped.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures |last=Shetterly |first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|page=129}}</ref> In an interview with [[WHRO-TV]], Katherine Johnson denied the feeling of segregation. "I didn't feel the segregation at NASA, because everybody there was doing research. You had a mission and you worked on it, and it was important to you to do your job ... and play bridge at lunch. I didn't feel any segregation. I knew it was there, but I didn't feel it."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historyvshollywood.com/reelfaces/hidden-figures/ |title=KATHERINE JOHNSON INTERVIEW: NASA'S HUMAN COMPUTER |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2016 |website=HistoryvsHollywood.com |publisher=CTF Media |accessdate=March 2, 2017 |quote=Citation:http://www.historyvshollywood.com/video/katherine-johnson-interview-nasa/}}</ref>
Mary Jackson did not have to get a court order to attend night classes at the whites-only high school. She asked the city of Hampton for an exception, and it was granted. The school turned out to be run down and dilapidated, a hidden cost of running two parallel school systems.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures|last=Shetterly|first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|pages=144–5}}</ref> She completed her engineering courses and earned a promotion to engineer in 1958.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/content/mary-jackson-biography |title=Mary Jackson Biography | NASA |publisher=Nasa.gov |date=December 2, 2016 |accessdate=January 30, 2017}}</ref>
Katherine Goble/Johnson carpooled with Eunice Smith, a nine-year West End computer veteran at the time Katherine joined NACA. Smith was her neighbor and friend from sorority and church choir.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures|last=Shetterly|first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|pages=120–1}}</ref> The three Goble children were teenagers at the time of Katherine's marriage to Jim Johnson.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures|last=Shetterly|first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|pages=185, 192}}</ref>
Katherine Goble/Johnson was assigned to the Flight Research Division in 1953, a move that soon became permanent. When the Space Task Group was created in 1958, engineers from the Flight Research Division formed the core of the Group, and Katherine moved along with them. She coauthored a research report in 1960, the first time a woman in the Flight Research Division had received credit as an author of a research report.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nasa.gov/content/katherine-johnson-biography |title=Katherine Johnson Biography |last=Shetterly |first=Margot Lee |date=December 1, 2016 |website=NASA |publisher=NASA |accessdate=March 2, 2017 |quote=authored or coauthored 26 research reports.}}</ref>
Katherine gained access to editorial meetings as of 1958 simply through persistence, not because one particular meeting was critical.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hidden Figures|last=Shetterly|first=Margot Lee|publisher=William Morrow|year=2016|isbn=978-0-06-236359-6|pages=179, 181–2}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Biographies/Johnson_Katherine.html |title=Katherine Coleman Goble Johnson |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=School of Mathematics & Statistics University of St Andrews, UK |publisher=School of Mathematics & Statistics University of St Andrews, UK |accessdate=March 1, 2017 |quote=Excerpt from W. Warren, Katherine Coleman Goble Johnson, in Black Women Scientists in the United States (Indiana University Press, 1999), 140-147.}}</ref>
The Space Task Group was led by [[Robert Gilruth]], not the fictional character Al Harrison, who was created to simplify a more complex management structure.
The scene where Harrison smashes the Colored Ladies Room sign never happened, as in real life Katherine refused to walk the extra distance to use the colored bathroom and, in her words, "just went to the White one".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/story/oscar-nominated-hidden-figures-was-whitewashed-but-it-didnt-have-to-be |title=''Space So White'' - Oscar-nominated "Hidden Figures" was whitewashed — but it didn't have to be |publisher=Vice.com |date= |accessdate=February 24, 2017}}</ref> Harrison also lets her into Mission Control to witness the launch. Neither scene happened in real life, and screenwriter Theodore Melfi said he saw no problem with adding the scenes, "There needs to be white people who do the right thing, there needs to be black people who do the right thing, and someone does the right thing. And so who cares who does the right thing, as long as the right thing is achieved?" Dexter Thomas of ''[[Vice News]]'' criticized Melfi's additions as creating the [[white savior narrative in film|white savior trope]], "In this case, it means that a white person doesn't have to think about the possibility that, were they around back in the 1960s South, they might have been one of the bad ones."<ref name="thomas">{{cite news |last=Thomas |first=Dexter |url=https://news.vice.com/story/oscar-nominated-hidden-figures-was-whitewashed-but-it-didnt-have-to-be |title=Space so white: The Oscar-nominated 'Hidden Figures' was whitewashed — but it didn't have to be |work=[[Vice News]] |date=January 25, 2017 |accessdate=February 2, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Atlantic]]''{{'}}s Megan Garber said that the film's "narrative trajectory" involved "thematic elements of the white savior".<ref name="garber">{{cite news |last=Garber |first=Megan |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/01/hidden-figures-and-the-appeal-of-math-in-an-age-of-inequality/513434/ |title=''Hidden Figures'' and the Appeal of Math in an Age of Inequality |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=January 18, 2017 |accessdate=February 2, 2017 |quote=''Hidden Figures''{{'}}s narrative trajectory involves not just progress that emerges, too often, from pettiness, but also thematic elements of the white savior, and of a culturally enforced tiara syndrome. All those things effectively temper the idealism of its message.}}</ref> Melfi said he found "hurtful" the "accusations of a 'white savior' storyline", saying, "It was very upsetting to me because I am at a place where I've lived my life colorless and I grew up in Brooklyn. I walked to school with people of all shapes, sizes, and colors, and that's how I've lived my life. So it's very upsetting that we still have to have this conversation. I get upset when I hear 'black film,' and so does Taraji P. Henson ... It's just a film. And if we keep labeling something 'a black film,' or 'a white film'— basically it's modern day segregation. We're all humans. Any human can tell any human's story. I don't want to have this conversation about black film or white film anymore. I wanna have conversations about film."
''[[The Huffington Post]]''{{'}}s Zeba Blay said of Melfi's frustration, "His frustration is also a perfect example of how, when it comes to open dialogue about depictions of people of color on screen, it behooves white people (especially those who position themselves as 'allies') to listen ... the inclusion of the bathroom scene doesn't make Melfi a bad filmmaker, or a bad person, or a racist. But his suggestion that a feel-good scene like that was needed for the marketability and overall appeal of the film speaks to the fact that Hollywood at large still has a long way to go in telling black stories, no matter how many strides have been made."<ref>{{cite news |last=Blay |first=Zeba |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hidden-figures-and-the-diversity-conversation-we-arent-having_us_58adc9bee4b0d0a6ef470492 |title='Hidden Figures' And The Diversity Conversation We Aren't Having |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=February 23, 2017 |accessdate=April 23, 2017}}</ref>
The fictional characters Vivian Mitchell and Paul Stafford are composites of several team members, and reflect common social views and attitudes of the time. Karl Zielinski is based on Mary Jackson's mentor, [[Kazimierz Czarnecki (engineer)|Kazimierz "Kaz" Czarnecki]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/modernfigures/faq |title=Modern Figures: Frequently Asked Questions | NASA |publisher=Nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=January 30, 2017}}</ref>
John Glenn, who was about a decade older than depicted at the time of launch, did ask specifically for Johnson<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/09/25/495179824/hidden-figures-how-black-women-did-the-math-that-put-men-on-the-moon |title='Hidden Figures': How Black Women Did The Math That Put Men On The Moon |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=September 25, 2016 |website=NPR |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=March 1, 2017 |quote=Heard on All Things Considered}}</ref> to verify the IBM calculations, although she had several days before the launch date to complete the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-010517a-hidden-figures-john-glenn-mystery.html |title='Hidden Figures': When did John Glenn ask for 'the girl' to check the numbers? |publisher=collectSPACE |date= |accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref>
The author Margot Lee Shetterly has agreed that there are differences between her book and the movie, but found that to be understandable. <blockquote>For better or for worse, there is history, there is the book and then there's the movie. Timelines had to be conflated and [there were] composite characters, and for most people [who have seen the movie] have already taken that as the literal fact. ... You might get the indication in the movie that these were the only people doing those jobs, when in reality we know they worked in teams, and those teams had other teams. There were sections, branches, divisions, and they all went up to a director. There were so many people required to make this happen. ... It would be great for people to understand that there were so many more people. Even though Katherine Johnson, in this role, was a hero, there were so many others that were required to do other kinds of tests and checks to make [Glenn's] mission come to fruition. But I understand you can't make a movie with 300 characters. It is simply not possible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/35145-hidden-figures-right-stuff-history.html |title='Hidden Figures': 'The Right Stuff' vs. Real Stuff in New Film About NASA History |last=Pearlman |first=Robert Z. |date=December 27, 2016 |website=Space.com |publisher=Purch |accessdate=March 2, 2017 |quote=Shetterly was still writing her book when production of the film began — it was only just released in September — but she was also available to the filmmakers as they sought to condense a story spanning a few decades into their setting of just a couple of years.}}</ref></blockquote>
John Glenn's flight was not terminated early as incorrectly stated in the movie's closing subtitles. The MA-6 mission was planned for three orbits and landed at the expected time. The press kit published before launch states that "The Mercury Operations Director may elect a one, two or three orbit mission." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://mira.hq.nasa.gov/history/ws/hdmshrc/all/main/DDD/16286.PDF |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525123504/https://mira.hq.nasa.gov/history/ws/hdmshrc/all/main/DDD/16286.PDF |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 25, 2009 |title=Mercury Atlas 6 at a Glance, page 1 |publisher=NASA |date= |accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref> The post mission report also shows that retrofire was scheduled to occur on the third orbit. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://science.ksc.nasa.gov/history/mercury/ma-6/docs/ma-6-results.pdf |title=Results of the First United States Manned Orbital Space Flight, Table 6-II Sequence of Events During MA-6 Flight, Page 71 |publisher=NASA |accessdate=November 12, 2017}}</ref> Scott Carpenter's subsequent flight in May was also scheduled and flew for three orbits, and Walter Schirra's planned six-orbit flight in October required extensive modifications to the Mercury capsule's life support system to allow him to fly a nine-hour mission.<ref>{{cite book|last=Baker|first=David|title=The History of Manned Space Flight, page 137|year=1981 |publisher=Crown Publishers|isbn= 0-517-54377-X}}</ref> The phrase "go for at least seven orbits" that is in the mission transcript refers to the fact that the Atlas booster had placed Glenn's capsule into an orbit that would be stable for at least seven orbits, not that he had permission to stay up that long.
The Mercury Control Center was located at Cape Canaveral, Florida, not at the Langley Research Center in Virginia. The orbit plots displayed in the front of the room incorrectly show a six-orbit mission, which did not happen until Walter Schirra's MA-8 mission in October 1962. The movie also incorrectly shows NASA flight controllers monitoring live telemetry from the Soviet Vostok launch, which the Soviet Union would not have been sharing with NASA in 1961.
Katherine Johnson's Technical Note D-233, co-written with T.H. Skopinski, can be found on the NASA Technical Reports Server.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?Ntx=mode+matchallany&Ntk=All&N=4293788881&Ntt=NASA+Technical+Note+D-233 |title=Determination of Azimuth Angle at Burnout for Placing a Satellite Over a Selected Earth Position |publisher=NASA |date= |accessdate=November 17, 2017}}</ref>
== Release == [[File:President Obama with the cast of Hidden Treasures.jpg|thumb|US President [[Barack Obama]] greeting Kevin Costner, Octavia Spencer, and Taraji P. Henson on December 15, 2016]] The film began a [[limited release]] on December 25, 2016, before a wide release on January 6, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/10/hidden-figures-gets-christmas-day-release-1201836941/|title=Fox Shifts 'Hidden Figures' To Christmas Day Limited Release|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Ross|last=A. Lincoln|date=October 14, 2016|accessdate=October 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hidden-figures-release-date-christmas-938618|title=It's Official: Fox's 'Hidden Figures' NASA Film to Get Oscar-Qualifying Limited Release|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Hilary|last=Lewis|date=October 15, 2016|accessdate=October 15, 2016}}</ref>
=== Charity screenings === After ''Hidden Figures'' was released on December 25, 2016, certain charities, institutions and independent businesses who regard the film as relevant to the cause of improving youth awareness in education and careers in the [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]] (STEM) fields, organized free screenings of the film in order to spread the message of the film's subject matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glamour.com/story/hidden-figures-inspiring-young-women-science-and-technology|title=The Hidden Figures Effect Is Real: How It's Inspiring Young Women to Seek Careers in Science and Technology|first=Marissa G.|last=Muller|date=January 30, 2017|work=[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref> A collaborative effort between Western New York STEM Hub, [[AT&T]] and the [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] allowed more than 200 Buffalo Public School students, [[Girl Scouts]] and teachers to see the film. WBFO's Senior Reporter Eileen Buckley stated the event was designed to help encourage a new generation of women to consider [[Women in STEM fields|STEM careers]]. Research indicates that by the year 2020, there will be 2.4 million unfilled STEM jobs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.wbfo.org/post/hidden-figures-inspire-city-students-pursue-stem-careers|title="Hidden Figures" to inspire city students to pursue STEM careers|first=Eileen|last=Buckley|date=February 1, 2017|work=[[WBFO]]|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref>
Also, the film's principal actors (Henson, Spencer, Monáe and Parsons), director (Melfi), producer/musical creator (Williams), and other non-profit outside groups have offered free screenings to ''Hidden Figures'' at several cinema locations around the world. Some of the screenings were open to all-comers, while others were arranged to benefit girls, women and the underprivileged. The campaign began as individual activism by Spencer, and made a total of more than 1,500 seats for ''Hidden Figures'' available, free of charge, to poor individuals and families. The end result was seven more screenings for people who otherwise might not have been able to afford to see the 20th Century Fox film - in Atlanta (sponsored by Monáe), in Washington, D.C. (sponsored by Henson), in Chicago (also Henson), in Houston (by Parsons), in Hazelwood, Missouri (by Melfi and actress/co-producer Kimberly Quinn), and in Norfolk and Virginia Beach, Virginia (both sponsored by Williams).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/hidden-figures-free-screenings-1201971825/|title=Free Screenings of 'Hidden Figures' Go Wide: From L.A. to Australia|first=James|last=Rainey|date=January 27, 2017|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref>
In February 2017, [[AMC Theatres]] and 21st Century Fox announced that free screenings of ''Hidden Figures'' would take place in celebration of [[Black History Month]] in up to 14 select U.S. cities (including Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles and Miami). The statement described the February charity screenings as building broader awareness of the film's true story of black women mathematicians who worked at NASA during the Space Race.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Hidden-Figures-Free-Screening-413750893.html|title=Free Screening of 'Hidden Figures' Offered for Black History Month|author=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 14, 2017|work=[[NBC Southern California]]|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref> 21st Century Fox and AMC Theatres also invited schools, community groups and non-profit organizations to apply for additional special screenings to be held in their towns. "As we celebrate [[Black History Month]] and look ahead to [[Women's History Month]] in March, this story of empowerment and perseverance is more relevant than ever," said Liba Rubenstein, 21st Century Fox's Senior Vice President of Social Impact, "We at 21CF were inspired by the grassroots movement to bring this film to audiences that wouldn't otherwise be able to see it - audiences that might include future innovators and barrier-breakers - and we wanted to support and extend that movement".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/hidden-figures-free-screenings-black-history-month-1201988170/|title='Hidden Figures' Set for Free Screenings in 14 Cities for Black History Month|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=February 14, 2017|work=Variety |accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref>
Philanthropic non-profit outside groups and other local efforts by individuals have offered free screenings of ''Hidden Figures'' by using [[crowdfunding]] platforms on the Internet, that allow people to raise money for free film screening events.<ref name="motto.time.com">{{cite web|url=http://motto.time.com/4639215/astronaut-hidden-figures-screening-gofundme/|title=This 7th Grader Wants to Send All the Young Girls in Her City to See 'Hidden Figures'|author=Lasher, Megan|date=January 27, 2017|work=time.com|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gofundme.com/mvc.php?route=category&term=hidden%20figures|title=Donate Online - Make Online Donations to People You Know!|author=|date=|work=[[gofundme.com]]|accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref> Dozens of other [[GoFundMe]] free screening campaigns have appeared since the film's general release, all by people wanting to raise money to pay for students to see the film.<ref name="motto.time.com"/>
===Merchandising=== Following the 2017 ''Lego Ideas Contest'', Denmark-based toy maker [[The Lego Group]] announced that will manufacture a fan-designed ''Women of NASA'' figurine set of five female scientists, engineers and astronauts, as based on real women who have worked for the NASA Space Agency. The [[Lego minifigure|minifigure]]s set did not end up including any of the figures from the film. It had computer scientist [[Margaret Hamilton (scientist)|Margaret Hamilton]]; astronaut, physicist and educator [[Sally Ride]]; astronomer [[Nancy Grace Roman]]; and astronaut and physician [[Mae Jemison]] (who is also African American). The ''Women of NASA'' set was released November 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2017/mar/01/hidden-figures-no-more-female-nasa-staff-to-be-immortalised-in-lego |title=Hidden figures no more: female Nasa staff to be immortalised in Lego |last=Malkin |first=Bonnie |date=February 28, 2017 |website=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/trending-now/lego-set-to-honor-women-of-nasa-including-katherine-johnson-of-hidden-figures_/498510195 |title=Lego set to honor women of NASA, including Katherine Johnson of 'Hidden Figures' |last=Ewing |first=Michelle |date=March 1, 2017 |publisher=[[WSB-TV]] |access-date=August 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>https://ideas.lego.com/blogs/a4ae09b6-0d4c-4307-9da8-3ee9f3d368d6/post/543b47ec-781a-4f32-a2f6-ca605c91f48b</ref>
===Home media=== ''Hidden Figures'' was released on Digital HD on March 28, 2017 and Blu-ray, 4K Ultra HD, and DVD on April 11, 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehdroom.com/bluray/hidden-figures-4k-blu-ray-dvd-digital-release-dates-details-107322/ |title='Hidden Figures' 4K, Blu-ray, DVD and Digital Release Dates and Details |publisher=TheHDRoom |accessdate=April 23, 2017}}</ref> The film debuted at No. 3 on the home video sales chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/force-remains-with-star-wars-for-dvd-blu-ray-disc-sales-1202390832/ |title=Force Remains With 'Star Wars' for DVD, Blu-ray Disc Sales |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=May 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Hidden Figures'' grossed $169.6 million in the United States and Canada, and $66.3 million in other territories, for a worldwide gross of $235.9 million, against a production budget of $25 million.<ref name=BOM/> Domestically, ''Hidden Figures'' was the highest-grossing Best Picture nominee at the 89th Academy Awards.<ref>{{cite web |work=Fortune |url=http://fortune.com/2017/02/27/moonlight-oscars-low-budget-box-office/ |title='Moonlight' Is Among the Lowest-Grossing Oscar Best Picture Winners Ever |author=Tom Huddleston, Jr. |date=February 27, 2017}}</ref> ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' calculated the net profit of the film to be $95.55 million, when factoring together all expenses and revenues for the film, making it one of the top twenty most profitable release of 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/03/hidden-figures-box-office-profit-2016-1202048264/|title=No. 15 ‘Hidden Figures’ Box Office Profits – 2016 Most Valuable Movie Blockbuster Tournament|author=Mike Fleming Jr|publisher=''[[Deadline Hollywood]]''|date=March 22, 2017|accessdate=March 23, 2017}}</ref>
During its limited release in 25 theaters from December 25, 2016 to January 5, 2017, the film grossed $3 million.<ref name=limited>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=daily&view=chart&id=hiddenfigures.htm|title=Hidden Figures (2016) - Daily Box Office Results - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=January 9, 2017}}</ref> In North America, ''Hidden Figures'' had its expansion alongside the opening of ''[[Underworld: Blood Wars]]'' and the wide expansions of ''[[Lion (2016 film)|Lion]]'' and ''[[A Monster Calls (film)|A Monster Calls]].'' It was expected to gross around $20 million from 2,471 theaters in its opening weekend, with the studio projecting a more conservative $15–17 million debut.<ref name="preview">{{Cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-movie-projector-20170103-story.html |title='Hidden Figures' is likely to draw crowds as 'Rogue One' stays on top of the box office |last=Faughnder |first=Ryan |date=January 4, 2017 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> It made $1.2 million from Thursday night previews and $7.6 million on its first day. Initially, projections had the film grossing $21.8 million in its opening weekend, finishing second behind ''[[Rogue One|Rogue One: A Star Wars Story]]'' ($22 million). Final figures revealed the film tallied a weekend total of $22.8 million, beating ''Rogue One''{{'}}s $21.9 million.<ref name="opening">{{Cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/rogue-one-hidden-figures-underworld-blood-wars-weekend-box-office-1201879773/ |title='Rogue One' Doesn't Want To Fall To 'Hidden Figures' As Winter Storm Helena Closes Theaters |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |date=January 9, 2017 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> In its second weekend, the film grossed $20.5 million (for a four-day [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day|MLK Weekend]] total of $27.5 million), again topping the box office.<ref name="opening2">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/patriots-day-sleepless-bye-bye-man-live-by-night-rogue-one-mlk-box-office-1201885490/|title='Hidden Figures' Stays Smart, But Why Are So Many Movies Bombing Over MLK Weekend?|last=D'Alessandro|first=Anthony|date=17 January 2017|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
=== Critical response === On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 93% based on 262 reviews, with an [[average score]] of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "In heartwarming, crowd-pleasing fashion, ''Hidden Figures'' celebrates overlooked—and crucial—contributions from a pivotal moment in American history."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hidden_figures/ |title=Hidden Figures (2017) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] |accessdate=March 21, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 74 out of 100, based on 47 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/hidden-figures |title=Hidden Figures Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=January 9, 2017}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A+" on an A+ to F scale,<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CinemaScore/status/817600462119702528 |title=''Hidden Figures'' |author=[[CinemaScore]] on [[Twitter]] |date=January 6, 2017 |accessdate=April 10, 2017}}</ref> one of fewer than 60 films in the history of the service to receive such a score.<ref name=opening/>
Simon Thompson of [[IGN]] gave the film a rating of 9/10, writing, "''Hidden Figures'' fills in an all too forgotten, or simply too widely unknown, blank in US history in a classy, engaging, entertaining and hugely fulfilling way. Superb performances across the board and a fascinating story alone make ''Hidden Figures'' a solid, an accomplished and deftly executed movie that entertains, engages and earns your time, money and attention."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.ign.com/articles/2016/12/14/hidden-figures-review|title=Hidden Figures|last=Thompson|first=Simon|date=14 December 2016|website=[[IGN]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref> [[Ty Burr]] of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' wrote, "the film's made with more heart than art and more skill than subtlety, and it works primarily because of the women that it portrays and the actresses who portray them. Best of all, you come out of the movie knowing who Katherine Johnson and Dorothy Vaughn and Mary Jackson are, and so do your daughters and sons."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2017/01/04/hidden-figures-history-lesson-with-math-appeal/GPfea4Sr2lqUDdJAwT09jI/story.html|title='Hidden Figures' is a crowd-pleaser with math appeal|last=Burr|first=Ty|date=4 January 2017|website=[[The Boston Globe]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
Clayton Davis of Awards Circuit gave the film 3.5 stars, saying "Precisely marketed as terrific adult entertainment for the Christmas season, ''Hidden Figures'' is a faithful and truly beautiful portrait of our country's consistent gloss over the racial tensions that have divided and continue to plague the fabric our existence. Lavishly engaging from start to finish, ''Hidden Figures'' may be able to catch the most inopportune movie-goer off guard and cause them to fall for its undeniable and classic storytelling. The film is not to be missed."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awardscircuit.com/2016/12/11/film-review-hidden-figures-is-pure-goodness-featuring-a-stellar-cast/|title=Film Review: 'Hidden Figures' Is Pure Goodness Featuring a Stellar Cast|last=Davis|first=Clayton|date=11 December 2016|website=AwardsCircuit|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=16 August 2018}}</ref>
Other reviews criticized the film for its fictional embellishments and conventional, feel-good style. Tim Grierson, writing for Screen International, states that "Hidden Figures is almost patronisingly earnest in its depiction of sexism and racism. An air of do-gooder self-satisfaction hovers over the proceedings",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.screendaily.com/reviews/hidden-figures-review/5111374.article|title='Hidden Figures': Review|last=Grierson|first=Tim|date=11 December 2016|website=[[Screen International]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> while Jesse Hassenger at [[The A.V. Club]] comments that "lack of surprise is in this movie's bones."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://film.avclub.com/good-performances-can-t-blast-hidden-figures-out-of-pre-1798189959|title=Good performances can't blast Hidden Figures out of prestige convention|last=Hassenger|first=Jese|date=20 December 2016|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> Eric John of IndieWire argues that the film "trivializes history; as a hagiographic tribute to its brilliant protagonists, it doesn't dig into the essence of their struggles"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/12/hidden-figures-review-octavia-spencer-taraji-p-henson-nasa-1201756595/|title=Hidden Figures Review|last=Kohn|first=Eric|date=11 December 2016|website=[[IndieWire]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref> and similarly, Paul Byrnes concludes that "When a film purports to be selling history, we're entitled to ask where the history went, even if it offers a good time instead."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/hidden-figures-review-these-trailblazing-women-deserve-better-20170214-gucbs5.html|title=Hidden Figures review: these trailblazing women deserve better|last=Byrnes|first=Paul|date=14 February 2017|website=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
=== Accolades === {{Main|List of accolades received by Hidden Figures}}

revision.text:
''This page is about the concept in [[mathematical logic]]. For the concept in [[sociology]], see [[Institutional logic]]''.
'''Institutional model theory''' generalizes a large portion of [[first-order logic|first-order]] [[model theory]] to an arbitrary [[logical system]].
== Overview == The notion of "logical system" here is formalized as an [[Institution (computer science)|institution]]. Institutions constitute a model-oriented meta-theory on logical systems similar to how the theory of [[Ring (mathematics)|ring]]s and [[Module (mathematics)|module]]s constitute a meta-theory for classical [[linear algebra]]. Another analogy can be made with [[universal algebra]] versus [[Group (mathematics)|group]]s, [[Ring (mathematics)|ring]]s, [[Module (mathematics)|module]]s etc. By abstracting away from the realities of the actual conventional logics, it can be noticed that institution theory comes in fact closer to the realities of non-conventional logics.
Institutional model theory analyzes and generalizes classical model-theoretic notions and results, like
* Elementary diagrams * [[Elementary embedding]]s * [[Ultraproduct]]s, [[Los' theorem]] * [[Saturated model]]s * [[Axiomatizable class|axiomatizability]] * [[Variety (universal algebra)|Varieties]], [[Garrett Birkhoff|Birkhoff]] axiomatizability * [[Craig interpolation]] * [[Robinson's joint consistency theorem|Robinson consistency]] * [[Evert Willem Beth|Beth]] definability * [[Gödel]]'s [[completeness theorem]]
For each concept and theorem, the infrastructure and properties required are analyzed and formulated as conditions on institutions, thus providing a detailed insight on which properties of first-order logic they rely and how much they can be generalized to other logics.
==References== {{Unreferenced|date=May 2009}}
==Further reading== * Razvan Diaconescu: [https://www.springer.com/birkhauser/mathematics/book/978-3-7643-8707-5 Institution-Independent Model Theory]. Birkhäuser, 2008. {{ISBN|978-3-7643-8707-5}}. * Razvan Diaconescu: Jewels of Institution-Independent Model Theory. In: K. Futatsugi, [[J.-P. Jouannaud]], J. Meseguer (eds.): Algebra, Meaning and Computation. Essays Dedicated to [[Joseph Goguen|Joseph A. Goguen]] on the Occasion of His 65th Birthday. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 4060, p. 65-98, Springer-Verlag, 2006. * Marius Petria and Rãzvan Diaconescu: Abstract Beth definability in institutions. Journal of Symbolic Logic 71(3), p. 1002-1028, 2006. * Daniel Gǎinǎ and Andrei Popescu: An institution-independent generalisation of Tarski's elementary chain theorem, Journal of Logic and Computation 16(6), p. 713-735, 2006. * Till Mossakowski, [[Joseph Goguen]], Rãzvan Diaconescu, Andrzej Tarlecki: What is a Logic?. In Jean-Yves Beziau, editor, Logica Universalis, pages 113-133. Birkhauser, 2005. * Andrzej Tarlecki: Quasi-varieties in abstract algebraic institutions. Journal of Computer and System Sciences 33(3), p. 333-360, 1986.
==External links== * [http://www.imar.ro/~diacon/publications.html#Institutions__institution-independent Razvan Diaconescu's publication list] - contains recent work on institutional model theory
[[Category:Theoretical computer science]] [[Category:Mathematical logic]] [[Category:Model theory]]

{{advert|date=June 2017}}
{{Infobox University |image =Jepson School of Leadership Studies.jpg |name = Jepson School of Leadership Studies |established = 1992 |type = [[Private school|Private]] |dean = Sandra J. Peart |city = [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] |state = [[Virginia]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |faculty = 15<ref name="Faculty">[http://jepson.richmond.edu/faculty/bios/index.html / Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Faculty]</ref> |campus = [[Suburban]] |website= [http://jepson.richmond.edu/ jepson.richmond.edu] |endowment= }}
The '''Jepson School of Leadership Studies''', founded in 1992 at the [[University of Richmond]], is dedicated to the academic study of [[leadership]]. The school is named for benefactors [[Robert S. Jepson, Jr.]], and his wife, Alice Andrews Jepson. The school opened as the first undergraduate school of [[leadership studies]] in the United States with a full-time multidisciplinary faculty.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/about/history/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: History|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Founding == {{paraphrasing|date=June 2017}} In 1987, Jepson School of Leadership Studies founders, Robert S. Jepson, Jr., and his wife, Alice, announced they would provide a $20 million challenge gift to develop a leadership studies program at the University of Richmond.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1989/06/05/program-to-usher-leadership-to-head-of-class-at-richmond-u/bca5ccb8-773c-41ff-98cf-d754a5be42d3/|title=Washington Post: Program to usher leadership to head of class at Richmond U.|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[E. Bruce Heilman]], [[Richard L. Morrill]], and Zeddie Brown were among the University leaders who helped form the school.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/about/history/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: History|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The first dean of the school was Howard T. Prince, who developed leadership programs for the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] and the [[United States Military Academy|U.S. Military Academy]] in West Point. [[James MacGregor Burns|James McGregor Burns]], a preeminent scholar in leadership studies, was named a senior fellow. The school's inaugural faculty included Joanne Ciulla, Richard Couto, Karin Klenke, William Howe,Gill Hickman, and J. Thomas Wren.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/about/history/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: History|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The first class entered the school in 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/about/history/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: History|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Norman Schwarzkopf Jr.|General Norman Schwarzkopf, Jr.]] spoke at the dedication of Jepson Hall on September 9, 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/09/09/Schwarzkopf-urges-students-to-cultivate-character-competence/5376716011200/|title=UPI: Schwarzkopf urges students to cultivate character, competence|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Leadership == === Deans === {| class="wikitable" |1990–1996 |Howard T. Prince |- |1996–2000 |John W. Rosenblum |- |2002–2006 |[[Kenneth P. Ruscio]] |- |2007–present |Sandra J. Peart |}
== Faculty == As of fall 2017, the Jepson School of Leadership Studies has 15 full-time faculty members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/faculty/bios/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Faculty|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Awards ===
Virginia State Council of Higher Education teaching awards: Joanne Ciulla (retired; 2003),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/faculty/bios/jciulla/|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Joanne Ciulla|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Don Forsyth (2002)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/faculty/bios/dforsyth/|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Donelson Forsyth|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Student life== === Student Activities === Students are elected annually to the Jepson Student Government Association, which acts a liaison between students and faculty and between Jepson School students and University of Richmond as well as organizing programs and speakers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orgsync.com/53525/chapter|title=University of Richmond Org Sync|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Students are appointed to the Jepson Corps, an emissary group that promotes the student experience, the Jepson School curriculum, and the School’s mission.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/major-minor/corps.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Jepson Corps|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Science Leadership Scholars Program is a co-curricular program offered through the Jepson School of Leadership Studies and the University of Richmond School of Arts and Sciences for students pursuing leadership studies and science.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/major-minor/science-leadership-scholars-program.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Science Leadership Scholars Program|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The program met for the first time in January 2016 at a dinner with journalist [[James Hamblin (journalist)|James Hamblin]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/13264/science-leadership-scholars-program-students-apply-leadership-studies-to-sciences-in-new-program.html|title=University of Richmond: Students apply leadership studies to sciences in new program|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
A collaboration with the [[University of Richmond School of Law]], the Jepson at Cambridge summer program allows students to spend five weeks studying at Emmanuel College, Cambridge University. Students participate in classes, lectures, and excursions to examine law and leadership in an international context.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/major-minor/cambridge.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Jepson at Cambridge|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Student Research === Students work with faculty members to research leadership as a part of the human condition. They may apply for grants to conduct full-time or part-time research with a faculty member during the summer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/research/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Research|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Students who have demonstrated scholarly drive and initiative may complete and defend a senior honors thesis in order to earn honors in leadership studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/major-minor/honors.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Honors|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Students present research projects at an annual symposium.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/research/symposium/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Student Research Symposium|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In recent years, students have presented research on the relationship effect of ADHD on leadership, the leadership impact of satirical news, and the impact of socioeconomic status on perceptions of leadership.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/14282/jepson-research-symposium-2017-student-scholarship-takes-center-stage-at-the-2017-jepson-research-symposium.html|title=University of Richmond: Student scholarship takes center stage at the 2017 Jepson Research Symposium|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The school’s annual Fredric M. Jablin Award for Undergraduate Research—given in memory of Dr. Fredric Jablin, a beloved professor and scholar at the school—is an annual award of $2,000 that is presented to a rising Jepson School senior conducting research in a wide variety of fields. The recipient is recognized at Finale, the Jepson School’s senior recognition and appreciation ceremony held each spring.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/research/jablin/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Fredric M. Jablin Award for Undergraduate Research|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Conferences and Teams === Four seniors are selected from the Leadership & Ethics capstone course annually to represent the Jepson School in the [[Association for Practical and Professional Ethics|APPE InterCollegiate Ethics Bowl]] competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://appe.indiana.edu/ethics-bowl/ethics-bowl/|title=APPE: Ethics Bowl|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The 2014–15 team finished in the top ten nationally.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/news/article/-/12481/jepson-schools-ethics-bowl-team-places-10th-in-national-competition.html|title=University of Richmond: Jepson School's ethics bowl team places 10th in national competition|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
Jepson School students attend conferences held throughout the country, including the Hatton W. Sumners Student Leadership Conference<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/13396/arthur-tartee-17-jepson-student-learns-about-integrity-and-leadership-ethics-at-student-conference.html|title=University of Richmond: Jepson student learns about integrity and leadership ethics at student conference|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and the [[United States Naval Academy|US Naval Academy]] Conference.
=== The Jepson EDGE Institute === Organized and led by Jepson School alumni, the Jepson EDGE Institute prepares students for success in life after college.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/major-minor/edge/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: EDGE|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Students network with alumni while developing strategies for securing and excelling in internships, jobs, graduate school, and post-collegiate life.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/14132/edge-2017-jepson-workshop-thrives-on-alumnis-commitment-to-students.html|title=University of Richmond: Jepson workshop thrives on alumni's commitment to students|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Programs == Every year, the Jepson Leadership Forum presents a series of programs that explore leadership topics around a theme. Forum speakers have included [[Elie Wiesel]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rpec.org/newsletters/199911.pdf|title=The Newsletter of the Richmond Peace Education Center|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Bill Moyers]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rpec.org/newsletters/199911.pdf|title=The Newsletter of the Richmond Peace Education Center|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Nina Totenberg]], [[Maria Konnikova]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/12991/how-to-make-smarter-choices-psychologist-and-bestselling-author-uses-sherlock-holmes-as-a-guide-to-making-smarter-choices.html|title=University of Richmond: Psychologist and bestselling author uses Sherlock Holmes as a guide to making smarter choices|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Peter Singer]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/releases/article/-/12903/2015-16-jepson-leadership-forum-to-focus-on-health-science-and-the-future-programs-free-but-registration-required.html|title=2015-16 Jepson Leadership Forum to focus on health, science and the future|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Annette Gordon-Reed]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/releases/article/-/13666/jepson-leadership-forum-will-explore-topics-related-to-racial-justice-.html|title=Jepson Leadership Forum will explore topics related to racial justice|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and [[Isabel Wilkerson]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/14056/isabel-wilkerson-2016-17-jepson-leadership-forum-hosts-bestselling-author-and-pulitzer-prize-winning-journalist.html|title=University of Richmond: 2016-17 Jepson Leadership Forum hosts bestselling author and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
The John Marshall International Center for the Study of Statesmanship hosts a variety of seminars, conferences, and speakers to explore topics surrounding constitutionalism, political economy, politics, and ethical reasoning.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/conferences/marshall/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: The John Marshall International Center for the Study of Statesmanship|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Speakers include [[Václav Klaus]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/11306/dinner-with-a-world-leader--former-president-of-the-czech-republic-v%C3%A1clav-klaus-visits-campus.html|title=University of Richmond: Former president of the Czech Republic Václav Klaus visits campus|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> [[Michael Hayden (general)|Gen. Michael V. Hayden]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bQfEtAaea5Q&feature=youtu.be|title=YouTube: Marshall Center Lecture Series: Gen. Michael V. Hayden|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Jennifer Rubin (journalist)|Jennifer Rubin]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/releases/article/-/13664/2016-17-marshall-center-lecture-series-focuses-on-leadership-and-law-speakers-include-former-cia-director-washington-post-blogger-.html|title=University of Richmond: 2016-17 Marshall Center lecture series focuses on leadership and law; speakers include former CIA director, Washington Post blogger|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and [[Harvey Mansfield|Harvey C. Mansfield]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/releases/article/-/12285/marshall-center-hosts-talks-on-leadership-and-economics-from-scholars-perspectives.html|title=University of Richmond: Marshall Center hosts talks on leadership and economics from scholars' perspectives|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The late [[Margaret Thatcher]] served as an adviser to the center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/news/article/-/9474/marshall-center-announces-2011-12-lecture-series.html|title=University of Richmond: Marshall Center announces 2011-12 Lecture Series|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2017, the Jepson School center hosted a conference surrounding Thatcher’s leadership with guests such as [[Robin Harris (author)|Robin Harris]], [[John R. Bolton|John Bolton]], and [[David Cannadine|Sir David Cannadine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/conferences/marshall/margaret-thatcher.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: The Leadership & Legacy of Margaret Thatcher|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Each academic year, notable leaders at the local, state, and national level are invited to serve as Leaders-in-Residence within the Jepson school. Particularly notable holders of this position have included: [[Leo K. Thorsness]], [[Tim Kaine]], [[Mary Sue Terry]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jepson.richmond.edu/faculty/leader-in-residence/index.html|title=Jepson School of Leadership Studies: Leader-in-Residence|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Leland D. Melvin|Leland Melvin]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.richmond.edu/features/article/-/500/leader-in-residence-2008-09-astronaut-leland-melvin-discusses-leadership-challenges-responsibility-and-nasa-at-50-.html|title=University of Richmond: Astronaut Leland Melvin discusses leadership, challenges, responsibility and NASA at 50|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and [[Vivian Pinn]].
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://jepson.richmond.edu/ Jepson School of Leadership Studies]
{{University of Richmond}}
